Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors of Hermitian Matrices

Recall the following definitions and properties:

Definitions. A Hermitian matrix AAA is such that A†=AA^{\dagger} = AA†=A, where A†A^{\dagger}A† denotes the complex conjugate of the transpose of AAA; the complex dot product is defined u⋅v\mathbf{u \cdot v}u⋅v, for two vectors u,v\mathbf{u, v}u,v, as being uiˉvi\bar{u_i}v_iui​ˉ​vi​.

Theorem. The eigenvalues of a Hermitian matrix are real.

Proof.

Let AAA be a Hermitian matrix. For eigenvalues x\mathbf{x}x and corresponding eigenvalues λ\lambdaλ of AAA, we have

Ax=λxA\mathbf{x} = \lambda\mathbf{x}Ax=λx

And thus

x†Ax=λx†x\mathbf{x^{\dagger}}A\mathbf{x} = \lambda\mathbf{x^{\dagger}x}x†Ax=λx†x

Taking the Hermitian conjugate of both sides gives

x†A†x=x†Ax=λ†x†x=λ∗x†x\mathbf{x^{\dagger}}A^{\dagger}\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{x^{\dagger}}A\mathbf{x} =\lambda^{\dagger}\mathbf{x^{\dagger}x} = \lambda^* \mathbf{x^{\dagger}x}x†A†x=x†Ax=λ†x†x=λ∗x†x

as A†=AA^{\dagger} = AA†=A by definition, and the Hermitian conjugate of a scalar λ\lambdaλ is just its conjugate. It thus follows that

λ∗x†x=λx†x,\lambda^* \mathbf{x^{\dagger}x}= \lambda \mathbf{x^{\dagger}x},λ∗x†x=λx†x,

and that

(λ∗−λ)x†x=0,(\lambda^* - \lambda)\mathbf{x^{\dagger}x} = 0,(λ∗−λ)x†x=0,

and as x†x≠0\mathbf{x^\dagger x} \neq 0x†x=0 unless x\mathbf{x}x is the zero vector (impossible if det⁡(A−λI)=0\det(A-\lambda I) = 0det(A−λI)=0, by definition), we have

λ∗=λ\lambda^* = \lambdaλ∗=λ

and thus λ\lambdaλ is real.

Corollary. As real symmetric matrices are also Hermitian, the eigenvalues of real symmetric matrices are real.

Proof (Adjoint maps).

Proceed with the following definitions:

Definition. For an inner product ⟨u,v⟩\langle\mathbf{u,v}\rangle⟨u,v⟩, define the adjoint A∗A^*A∗ to a linear map AAA as such that ⟨Au,v⟩=⟨u,A∗v⟩\langle A\mathbf{u,v}\rangle = \langle \mathbf{u}, A^*\mathbf{v} \rangle⟨Au,v⟩=⟨u,A∗v⟩.

Definition. Self-adjoint maps AAA are such that AAA is its own adjoint over some inner product (e.g. the dot product).

Hermitian matrices are self-adjoint maps over the complex dot product; that is, they satisfy

u⋅(Av)=(Au)⋅v\mathbf{u} \cdot (A\mathbf{v}) = (A\mathbf{u}) \cdot \mathbf{v}u⋅(Av)=(Au)⋅v

where ⋅\cdot⋅ denotes the complex dot product (in contrast, real symmetric matrices are self-adjoint over the real dot product).

Proof that Hermitian matrices are self-adjoint. The complex dot product between AuA\mathbf{u}Au and v\mathbf{v}v can also be expressed in matrix form as

(Au)†v.(A\mathbf{u})^{\dagger} \mathbf{v}.(Au)†v.

Taking the Hermitian transpose of this gives

v†(Au)\mathbf{v}^{\dagger} (A\mathbf{u})v†(Au)

which, as A†=AA^{\dagger} = AA†=A, equals

v†A†u=(Av)†u\mathbf{v}^{\dagger} A^{\dagger} \mathbf{u} = (A\mathbf{v})^{\dagger} \mathbf{u}v†A†u=(Av)†u

which is (Av)⋅u(A\mathbf{v}) \cdot \mathbf{u}(Av)⋅u. The proof that symmetric matrices are self-adjoint follows similarly.

We can utilize the properties of self-adjoint matrices particularly well here. Let x\mathbf{x}x be an eigenvector of AAA and consider the norm

λ(x⋅x).\lambda(\mathbf{x}\cdot \mathbf{x}).λ(x⋅x).

By Ax=λxA\mathbf{x} = \lambda \mathbf{x}Ax=λx, we have

λ(x⋅x)=(λx⋅x)=(Ax⋅x)=(x⋅Ax)=(x⋅λx)=λ∗(x⋅x)\begin{aligned} &\lambda(\mathbf{x}\cdot \mathbf{x}) \\ &= (\lambda \mathbf{x}\cdot \mathbf{x}) \\ &= (A\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{x}) \\ &= (\mathbf{x} \cdot A\mathbf{x}) \\ &= (\mathbf{x} \cdot \lambda \mathbf{x}) \\ &= \lambda^* (\mathbf{x}\cdot \mathbf{x}) \end{aligned}​λ(x⋅x)=(λx⋅x)=(Ax⋅x)=(x⋅Ax)=(x⋅λx)=λ∗(x⋅x)​

by the properties of the complex dot product (non-commutative because of a conjugate). As (x⋅x)>0(\mathbf{x}\cdot \mathbf{x}) > 0(x⋅x)>0 (x≠0\mathbf{x} \neq 0x=0), we have λ=λ∗\lambda = \lambda^*λ=λ∗.

Theorem. A n×nn\times nn×n Hermitian matrix AAA has nnn orthogonal eigenvectors.

To prove this, we need to introduce a powerful tool:

Theorem. Gram-Schmidt Process.

The Gram-Schmidt process yields an orthogonal set of rrr vectors B~={v1,v2,...,vr}\tilde{B} = \{\mathbf{v_1,v_2,...,v_r}\}B~={v1​,v2​,...,vr​} from rrr linearly independent vectors B={w1,w2,...,wr}B = \{\mathbf{w_1,w_2,...,w_r}\}B={w1​,w2​,...,wr​}.

First define the projection operator Pv(w)P_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{w})Pv​(w) as an orthogonal projection of the vector w\mathbf{w}w onto the direction of v\mathbf{v}v:

Pv(w)=v⋅wv⋅vv.P_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{w}) = \frac{\mathbf{v\cdot w}}{\mathbf{v \cdot v}}\mathbf{v}.Pv​(w)=v⋅vv⋅w​v.

This projection works by first constructing a vector that is a scalar multiple of v\mathbf{v}v: Pv(w)=λvP_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{w}) = \lambda\mathbf{v}Pv​(w)=λv for some v\mathbf{v}v. As Pv(w)P_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{w})Pv​(w) is a projection of w\mathbf{w}w onto v\mathbf{v}v, it has magnitude equal to ∣w∣cos⁡θ|\mathbf{w}|\cos \theta∣w∣cosθ where θ\thetaθ is the angle between the two vectors. Thus we have

∣λv∣=∣w∣cos⁡θλ2(v⋅v)=(w⋅w)cos⁡2θλ2=(w⋅w)(v⋅v)cos⁡2θ\begin{aligned} |\lambda\mathbf{v}| &= |\mathbf{w}|\cos \theta \\ \lambda^2 (\mathbf{v}\cdot \mathbf{v}) &= (\mathbf{w}\cdot\mathbf{w})\cos^2 \theta \\ \lambda^2 &= \frac{(\mathbf{w}\cdot\mathbf{w})}{(\mathbf{v}\cdot \mathbf{v})}\cos^2 \theta \\ \end{aligned}∣λv∣λ2(v⋅v)λ2​=∣w∣cosθ=(w⋅w)cos2θ=(v⋅v)(w⋅w)​cos2θ​

as cos⁡2θ=(w⋅v)2(w⋅w)(v⋅v)\cos^2 \theta = \frac{(\mathbf{w \cdot v})^2}{(\mathbf{w\cdot w})(\mathbf{v\cdot v})}cos2θ=(w⋅w)(v⋅v)(w⋅v)2​ by the properties of the dot product, we have

λ=v⋅wv⋅v.\lambda = \frac{\mathbf{v\cdot w}}{\mathbf{v \cdot v}}.λ=v⋅vv⋅w​.

Also observe that w−Pv(w)\mathbf{w} - P_\mathbf{v}(\mathbf{w})w−Pv​(w) is the normal vector from w\mathbf{w}w to v\mathbf{v}v, and is thus orthogonal to v\mathbf{v}v. This gives us a clue on how to begin our Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process for B={w1,w2,...,wn}B = \{\mathbf{w_1,w_2,...,w_n}\}B={w1​,w2​,...,wn​} to orthogonal vectors B~={v1,v2,...,vn}\tilde{B} = \{\mathbf{v_1,v_2,...,v_n\}}B~={v1​,v2​,...,vn​}:

  1. Let v1=w1\mathbf{v}_1 = \mathbf{w_1}v1​=w1​.
  2. We want v2\mathbf{v_2}v2​ to be orthogonal to v1\mathbf{v}_1v1​. Therefore, let v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​ be the perpendicular from w2\mathbf{w}_2w2​ onto v1\mathbf{v_1}v1​: v2=w2−Pv1(w2)\mathbf{v_2} = \mathbf{w_2} - P_{\mathbf{v_1}}(\mathbf{w_2})v2​=w2​−Pv1​​(w2​).
  3. We want v3\mathbf{v_3}v3​ to be orthogonal to both v1\mathbf{v}_1v1​ and v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​. Thus let v3\mathbf{v}_3v3​ be the perpendicular from w3\mathbf{w}_3w3​ to both v1\mathbf{v_1}v1​ and v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​: v3=w3−Pv1(w3)−Pv2(w3)\mathbf{v}_3 = \mathbf{w}_3 - P_{\mathbf{v_1}}(\mathbf{w}_3) - P_{\mathbf{v_2}}(\mathbf{w}_3)v3​=w3​−Pv1​​(w3​)−Pv2​​(w3​).
  4. ⋮\vdots⋮
  5. We want vn\mathbf{v_n}vn​ to be orthogonal to v1,v2,...,vn−1\mathbf{v_1}, \mathbf{v_2}, ..., \mathbf{v_{n-1}}v1​,v2​,...,vn−1​, so let vn\mathbf{v_n}vn​ to be the perpendicular of wn\mathbf{w}_nwn​ to all of the above vectors: vn=wn−∑i=1n−1Pvi(wn)\mathbf{v}_n = \mathbf{w}_n - \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}P_{\mathbf{v}_{i}}(\mathbf{w}_n)vn​=wn​−∑i=1n−1​Pvi​​(wn​).

In each step, we construct vi\mathbf{v}_ivi​ from the difference between wi\mathbf{w}_iwi​ and its orthogonal projection to the vector space formed by v1,v2,...,vi−1\mathbf{v}_1, \mathbf{v}_2, ..., \mathbf{v}_{i-1}v1​,v2​,...,vi−1​, thus yielding an orthogonal vector to all the previous v\mathbf{v}vs.

Proof that the Gram-Schmidt process yields a list of orthogonal vectors.

Proceed by induction. First, the base case: v1\mathbf{v}_1v1​ and v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​ are orthogonal by definition of the projection operator (v2\mathbf{v}_2v2​ is perpendicular to a projection onto v1\mathbf{v}_1v1​.) If we can prove that any consecutive sequence of vectors in B~\tilde{B}B~ are orthogona, then we can prove that they are mutually orthogonal.

Suppose that v1,v2,...,vk\mathbf{v}_1, \mathbf{v}_2, ..., \mathbf{v}_{k}v1​,v2​,...,vk​ are an orthogonal list of vectors; that is, suppose that

vi⋅vj=0\mathbf{v}_i \cdot \mathbf{v}_j = 0vi​⋅vj​=0

for all i,j=1,2,...,ki, j = 1, 2, ..., ki,j=1,2,...,k and i≠ji \neq ji=j. We want to prove that vk+1\mathbf{v}_{k+1}vk+1​ is orthogonal to this list. Consider, for any j=1,2,...,kj = 1, 2, ..., kj=1,2,...,k,

vj⋅vk+1=vj⋅(wk+1−∑i=1kPvi(wk+1))=vj⋅(wk+1−∑i=1kvi⋅wk+1vi⋅vivi)=vj⋅wk+1−∑i=1kvi⋅wk+1vi⋅vivj⋅vi\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}_j \cdot \mathbf{v}_{k+1} \\ = \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot (\mathbf{w}_{k+1} - \sum_{i=1}^{k}P_{\mathbf{v}_i} (\mathbf{w}_{k+1})) \\ = \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot (\mathbf{w}_{k+1} - \sum_{i=1}^{k}\frac{\mathbf{v_i \cdot w_{k+1}}}{\mathbf{v_i \cdot v_i}} \mathbf{v}_i) \\ = \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot \mathbf{w}_{k+1} - \sum_{i=1}^{k}\frac{\mathbf{v_i \cdot w_{k+1}}}{\mathbf{v_i \cdot v_i}} \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot\mathbf{v}_i \end{aligned}vj​⋅vk+1​=vj​⋅(wk+1​−i=1∑k​Pvi​​(wk+1​))=vj​⋅(wk+1​−i=1∑k​vi​⋅vi​vi​⋅wk+1​​vi​)=vj​⋅wk+1​−i=1∑k​vi​⋅vi​vi​⋅wk+1​​vj​⋅vi​​

where, as vi⋅vj=0\mathbf{v}_i \cdot \mathbf{v}_j = 0vi​⋅vj​=0 for all i≠ji \neq ji=j, the sum has its only nonzero term as i=ji = ji=j:

=vj⋅wk+1−vj⋅wk+1vj⋅vjvj⋅vj= \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot \mathbf{w}_{k+1} - \frac{\mathbf{v_j \cdot w_{k+1}}}{\mathbf{v_j \cdot v_j}} \mathbf{v}_{j} \cdot\mathbf{v}_j=vj​⋅wk+1​−vj​⋅vj​vj​⋅wk+1​​vj​⋅vj​

which is zero. Thus, by the principle of mathematical induction, vk+1\mathbf{v}_{k+1}vk+1​ is orthogonal to the list v1,v2,...,vk\mathbf{v_1, v_2, ..., v_k}v1​,v2​,...,vk​. □\square□

The extra wao sugoi thing about the Gram-Schmidt process is that it doesn't just give us a list of orthogonal vectors; it gives us a list of basis vectors of Fn\mathbf{F}^nFn, from any list of nnn vectors in Fn\mathbf{F}^nFn. This is owing to

Theorem. Any set of nonzero orthogonal vectors is also linearly independent (and thus a basis).

Proof.

Suppose for the sake of contradiction that {v1,v2,...,vn}\{\mathbf{v_1, v_2, ..., v_n}\}{v1​,v2​,...,vn​} is a list of orthogonal vectors (all of which are nonzero), and that there exist scalars a1,...,ana_1, ..., a_na1​,...,an​, not all zero, such that

∑i=1naivi=0\sum_{i=1}^n a_i \mathbf{v_i} = 0i=1∑n​ai​vi​=0

violating linear independence. Taking the dot product with vK\mathbf{v_K}vK​ for some K=1,2,...,nK = 1, 2, ..., nK=1,2,...,n yields

∑i=1nai(vi⋅vK)=0\sum_{i=1}^n a_i (\mathbf{v_i} \cdot \mathbf{v_K}) = 0i=1∑n​ai​(vi​⋅vK​)=0

but as the dot product of any vi,vK\mathbf{v_i, v_K}vi​,vK​, i≠Ki \neq Ki=K, is zero by definition of an orthogonal set of vectors, the above sum is only nonzero when i=Ki = Ki=K. Thus, it is equivalent to the single term

aK(vK⋅vK)=0a_K (\mathbf{v_K \cdot v_K}) = 0aK​(vK​⋅vK​)=0

vK\mathbf{v}_KvK​ is nonzero and thus has nonzero norm; thus, aK=0a_K = 0aK​=0. However, the above process can be conducted with any K=1,2,...,nK = 1, 2, ..., nK=1,2,...,n, leading to the conclusion that

ai=0a_i = 0ai​=0

for all i=1,2,...,ni = 1, 2, ..., ni=1,2,...,n. This forms a contradiction.

Remark.

  1. A set of nnn mutually orthogonal vectors form a basis in Fn\mathbb{F}^nFn.
  2. Each vn\mathbf{v}_nvn​ is a linear combination of the wn\mathbf{w}_nwn​.
  3. If w1,w2,...,wn\mathbf{w_1, w_2, ..., w_n}w1​,w2​,...,wn​ is a list of linearly dependent vectors, the Gram-Schmidt process will not be able to generate a full list of nnn orthogonal vectors; if wk\mathbf{w}_kwk​ is the first linearly dependent vector in w\mathbf{w}w, then vk=0\mathbf{v}_k = 0vk​=0. This is because vk\mathbf{v}_kvk​ is a linear combination of w1,...,wk\mathbf{w}_1, ..., \mathbf{w}_kw1​,...,wk​.
  4. If a set of linearly independent eigenvectors B={w1,...,wr}B = \{\mathbf{w_1,...,w_r}\}B={w1​,...,wr​} yields an orthogonal set of vectors B~={v1,...,vr}\tilde{B} = \{\mathbf{v_1, ..., v_r}\}B~={v1​,...,vr​} by Gram-Schmidt, then B~\tilde{B}B~ also constitutes a set of eigenvectors because B~\tilde{B}B~ is a linear combination of BBB.

Definition. An orthonormal set, as previously defined is an orthogonal set of vectors {u1,u2,...,un}\{\mathbf{u_1, u_2, ..., u_n}\}{u1​,u2​,...,un​} such that

ui⋅uj=δij,\mathbf{u_i} \cdot \mathbf{u_j} = \delta_{ij},ui​⋅uj​=δij​,

i.e. the vectors are mutually orthogonal (have dot product zero) and each of norm 1. An orthogonal set can be converted to an orthonormal set simply by normalizing each vector to norm 1.

Remark. If BBB is an orthogonal set that forms a set of eigenvectors, then the orthonormal set B~\tilde{B}B~ constructed from BBB is also a set of eigenvectors (owing to eigenspaces being subspaces).

Theorem. Transformation matrices between two orthonormal bases are unitary.

Proof.

Suppose that the two bases u={u1,...,un}u = \{\mathbf{u_1, ..., u_n}\}u={u1​,...,un​} and v={v1,...,vn}v = \{\mathbf{v_1, ..., v_n\}}v={v1​,...,vn​} are orthonormal; we have ui⋅uj=vi⋅vj=δij\mathbf{u_i \cdot u_j = v_i \cdot v_j} = \delta_{ij}ui​⋅uj​=vi​⋅vj​=δij​. The transformation matrix mapping uuu to vvv can be denoted

U=[U11U12...U1nU21U22...U2n⋮⋮⋱⋮Un1Un2...Unn]U = \begin{bmatrix} U_{11} & U_{12} & ... & U_{1n} \\ U_{21} & U_{22} & ... & U_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ U_{n1} & U_{n2} & ... & U_{nn} \end{bmatrix}U=⎣⎡​U11​U21​⋮Un1​​U12​U22​⋮Un2​​......⋱...​U1n​U2n​⋮Unn​​⎦⎤​

where

vj=∑i=1nUijui\mathbf{v}_j = \sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij} \mathbf{u}_ivj​=i=1∑n​Uij​ui​

with its columns expressing the basis vvv in terms of the vectors of uuu. We want to prove that this matrix is unitary, i.e. that

U†U=IU^{\dagger} U = IU†U=I

or, in scalar form, that

Uik†Ukj=Uki∗Ukj=δijU^{\dagger}_{ik} U_{kj} = U^*_{ki} U_{kj} = \delta_{ij}Uik†​Ukj​=Uki∗​Ukj​=δij​

As vj⋅vk=0\mathbf{v}_j \cdot \mathbf{v}_k = 0vj​⋅vk​=0 for i≠ji \neq ji=j, we have

(∑i=1nUijui)⋅(∑r=1nUrkui)=0\begin{aligned} (\sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij} \mathbf{u}_i) \cdot (\sum_{r=1}^n U_{rk} \mathbf{u}_i) = 0 \end{aligned}(i=1∑n​Uij​ui​)⋅(r=1∑n​Urk​ui​)=0​

where the only term in the sum that is nonzero is when i=ri=ri=r, i.e.

∑i=1nUij∗Uik(ui⋅ui)=0.\sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij}^* U_{ik}(\mathbf{u_i} \cdot \mathbf{u_i}) = 0.i=1∑n​Uij∗​Uik​(ui​⋅ui​)=0.

(The complex conjugate arises due to the dot product being the complex scalar product). As ui⋅ui=1\mathbf{u}_i \cdot \mathbf{u}_i = 1ui​⋅ui​=1 by orthonormality, we have

∑i=1nUij∗Uik=0\sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij}^* U_{ik} = 0i=1∑n​Uij∗​Uik​=0

for j≠kj \neq kj=k.

As vj⋅vj=1\mathbf{v}_j \cdot \mathbf{v}_j = 1vj​⋅vj​=1, we have

(∑i=1nUijui)⋅(∑r=1nUrjui)=1\begin{aligned} (\sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij} \mathbf{u}_i) \cdot (\sum_{r=1}^n U_{rj} \mathbf{u}_i) = 1 \end{aligned}(i=1∑n​Uij​ui​)⋅(r=1∑n​Urj​ui​)=1​

or that

∑i=1nUij∗Uij=1\sum_{i=1}^n U_{ij}^* U_{ij} = 1i=1∑n​Uij∗​Uij​=1

As such we conclude from the above that

Uij∗Uik=δjkU_{ij}^* U_{ik} = \delta_{jk}Uij∗​Uik​=δjk​

using suffix notation, or Uki∗Ukj=δijU^*_{ki} U_{kj} = \delta_{ij}Uki∗​Ukj​=δij​. Thus UUU is unitary. □\square□

Theorem. A n×nn\times nn×n Hermitian matrix HHH has nnn orthogonal, and thus linearly independent, eigenvectors.

Proof.

We present the following alternatives:

  1. Proof by condescension. The statement is trivial and thus does not require a proof.
  2. Proof a la Pierre de Fermat. I have devised a truly marvelous proof of this theorem, but it is too large to fit inside my computer's hard drive.
  3. Proof by appeal to authority. My textbook says so, so it must be true.
  4. Proof by slippery slope. If Hermitian matrices don't have nnn orthogonal eigenvectors, then soon enough symmetric matrices aren't going to have orthogonal eigenvectors too and the universe will die a slow, painful, tortured heat death.
  5. Proof by emotional appeal.

(I'm going to get out of here and never come back)

Suppose that λi\lambda_iλi​ and λj\lambda_jλj​ are two eigenvalues of HHH, not necessarily distinct, corresponding to eigenvectors viv_ivi​ and vjv_jvj​ respectively. Our goal is to prove that viv_ivi​ and vjv_jvj​ are orthogonal, i.e. vi⋅vj=0v_i \cdot v_j = 0vi​⋅vj​=0; in matrix form, this can be expressed as vi†vj=0v_i^{\dagger} v_j = 0vi†​vj​=0 (using the complex scalar product).

Case 1: λi≠λj\lambda_i \neq \lambda_jλi​=λj​. In any case, we have Hvi=λviHv_i = \lambda v_iHvi​=λvi​ and Hvj=λvjH v_j = \lambda v_jHvj​=λvj​.

Now consider the (complex) dot product between viv_ivi​ and vjv_jvj​, vi†vjv_i^{\dagger} v_jvi†​vj​. If Hvj=λjvjHv_j = \lambda_j v_jHvj​=λj​vj​, then we have

vi†Hvj=vi†λjvjv_i^{\dagger}Hv_j = v_i^{\dagger} \lambda_j v_jvi†​Hvj​=vi†​λj​vj​

where taking the Hermitian transpose of both sides gives

vj†H†vi=vj†λj∗viv_j^{\dagger} H^{\dagger} v_i = v_j^{\dagger}\lambda_j^* v_ivj†​H†vi​=vj†​λj∗​vi​

where H†=HH^{\dagger} = HH†=H, so

vj†Hvi=vj†λivi=vj†λj∗viv_j^{\dagger} H v_i = v_j^{\dagger} \lambda_i v_i = v_j^{\dagger}\lambda_j^* v_ivj†​Hvi​=vj†​λi​vi​=vj†​λj∗​vi​

as Hvi=λiviHv_i = \lambda_i v_iHvi​=λi​vi​. Thus (λi∗−λj)(vj†vi)=0(\lambda_i^* - \lambda_j) (v_j^{\dagger} v_i) = 0(λi∗​−λj​)(vj†​vi​)=0. However, as proven above, the eigenvalues of HHH are real, so λi∗=λi≠λj\lambda_i^* = \lambda_i \neq \lambda_jλi∗​=λi​=λj​, and so vj†vi=0v_j^\dagger v_i = 0vj†​vi​=0. (This can also be proven using self-adjoint maps).

Case 2: λi=λj\lambda_i = \lambda_jλi​=λj​ (repeated eigenvalue). Suppose that HHH has distinct eigenvalues λ1,λ2,...,λr\lambda_1, \lambda_2, ..., \lambda_rλ1​,λ2​,...,λr​, with the other n−rn-rn−r eigenvalues being repeated. By Case 1 (distinct eigenvalues correspond to orthogonal/orthonormal eigenvectors), the corresponding eigenvectors {v1,v2,...,vr}\{\mathbf{v_1,v_2,...,v_r}\}{v1​,v2​,...,vr​} form an orthonormal set. Let

v={v1,v2,...,vr,u1,u2,...,un−r}v = \{\mathbf{v_1,v_2,...,v_r,u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n-r}\}}v={v1​,v2​,...,vr​,u1​,u2​,...,un−r​}

be an orthonormal basis for Fn\mathbb{F}^nFn; by Gram-Schmidt, such an orthonormal basis can always be found containing v1,...,vr\mathbf{v_1,...,v_r}v1​,...,vr​ (which are orthonormal, and thus not affected by Gram-Schmidt) by selecting any basis containg v1,v2,...,vr\mathbf{v_1,v_2,...,v_r}v1​,v2​,...,vr​ and applying the process. Thus let PPP represent the transformation matrix from the original basis of HHH to the orthonormal basis vvv, i.e.

P=[v1v2...vru1u2...un−r]P = \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{v_1} & \mathbf{v_2} & ... & \mathbf{v_r} & \mathbf{u_1} & \mathbf{u_2} & ... & \mathbf{u_{n-r}} \end{bmatrix}P=[v1​​v2​​...​vr​​u1​​u2​​...​un−r​​]

By the above theorem, PPP is unitary with P†=P−1P^{\dagger} = P^{-1}P†=P−1. As such, HHH with basis changed to vvv is

P−1HP=P†HP=(P†HP)†P^{-1} H P = P^{\dagger} H P = (P^{\dagger} H P )^{\dagger}P−1HP=P†HP=(P†HP)†

Corollary.

  1. The eigenvectors of Hermitian matrices can always form an orthonormal basis for Cn\mathbb{C}^nCn.
  2. Hermitian matrices are always diagonalizable; in particular, they are diagonalizable by unitary matrices, as the transformation matrix from the standard orthonormal basis to the basis of eigenvectors (orthonormal) is unitary by an above theorem.
  3. All of the above also applies to (real) symmetric matrices: they have orthogonal eigenvectors, have real eigenvalues, and are diagonalizable by orthogonal matrices instead of unitary matrices.
